docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: One key factor in the cost and potential value of covering the 44 million Americans with no or inadequate health insurance was omitted from your Dec. 27 editorial ''Two Visions on Health Care.''

headline.main: The Cost of Health Care: More Than Money

docs.snippet: To the Editor:    One key factor in the cost and potential value of covering the 44 million Americans with no or inadequate health insurance was omitted from your Dec. 27 editorial ''Two Visions on Health Care.''

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Two Visions on Health Care'' (editorial, Dec. 27):

headline.main: The Cost of Health Care: More Than Money

docs.snippet: To the Editor:     Re ''Two Visions on Health Care'' (editorial, Dec. 27):

docs.lead_paragraph: Englewood Hospital and Medical Center's frequent radio ads boast of a ''world class'' staff that treats patients with respect. But there is one class of patient that the hospital will no longer treat at all: the kind enrolled in a Blue Cross/Blue Shield health maintenance plan. The hospital -- citing what it called inadequate reimbursements and meddling in medical decisions for its HMO subscribers -- announced recently that it was cancelling its contract with Horizon Blue Cross/Blue Shield of New Jersey and with Empire Blue Cross/Blue Shield of New York, effective Feb. 22.

headline.main: For Hospital and H.M.O., a Parting of the Ways

docs.abstract: Article on decision by Englewood Hospital and Medical Center to cancel contract with Horizon Blue Cross/Blue Shield of New Jersey and with Empire Blue Cross/Blue Shield of New York, citing inadequate reimbursements of doctors and meddling in medical decisions for its HMO subscribers; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THEY never made the cover of People magazine. Sometimes they didn't even make headlines in their community's weekly newspaper. But they made a difference in the way they lived. And they made a difference in Connecticut, where they lived.

headline.main: Lives Lived Well And the Lesson That They Teach

docs.abstract: Vignettes of some Connecticut residents who died in 1999 whose lives enriched communities where they lived and people they lived with; photos (M)
docs.snippet: THEY never made the cover of People magazine. Sometimes they didn't even make headlines in their community's weekly newspaper.     But they made a difference in the way they lived. And they made a difference in Connecticut, where they lived.

docs.lead_paragraph: The owners of a handful of fruit and vegetable markets in the East Village agreed yesterday to allow their workers to join unions, ending a bitter six-month boycott that crippled their business and turned their stores into neighborhood pariahs. Although the number of affected workers is small, labor organizers said the agreement was unprecedented. For the first time, union officials said, workers in the city's ubiquitous markets will be paid at least the minimum wage and will receive health insurance and other benefits. Organizers said they hoped that the settlement would lead to similar agreements with thousands of other greengrocers in New York, most of which are owned by Korean immigrants who employ Mexicans.

headline.main: Produce Market Owners Allow Workers to Unionize

docs.abstract: Owners of handful of fruit and vegetable markets in East Village agree to allow their workers to join unions, ending bitter six-month boycott that crippled their business and turned their stores into neighborhood pariahs; labor organizers hail agreement, saying that for first time, workers in city's ubiquitous markets will be paid at least minimum wage and will receive health insurance and other benefits; they will be represented by Union of Needletrades, Industrial and Textile Employees; union officials hope settlement will lead to agreements with thousands of other greengrocers in New York, most of which are owned by Korean immigrants who employ Mexicans; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Sam Shapiro, a health care analyst and biostatistician whose studies in the 1960's proved that mammograms saved women's lives by catching breast cancers at an early, treatable stage, died on Thursday at his home in Baltimore. He was 85. Professor Shapiro, working with Dr. Philip Strax, used his statistical expertise to persuade a skeptical medical establishment of the value of mammography. At the time such screenings were rarely used and little was known of their effects.

headline.main: Sam Shapiro, 68, Pioneer in Use of Mammograms

docs.abstract: Prof Sam Shapiro, health care analyst and biostatistician whose studies proved that mammograms save women's lives, dies at age of 85; photo (M)
